Where do most members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints live?
Originally Answered: Where do most Latter-day Saints live?

Good question. Most means more than 50%, so to get to that magic majority of Latter-day Saints (i.e. members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, or saints for short), you have to take all of the church members living in the following states and countries as of sometime in 2017 when the Church last provided the statistics currently (Feb 2019) available on its website (lds.org):

Utah - 2,090,402
Mexico - 1,435,383
Brazil - 1,383,799
California - 767,301
Philippines - 765,393
Chile - 590,124
Peru - 590,124
Argentina - 452,309

The above numbers represent the data you get if you treat states as countries, which makes sense to me given that you cant even answer the question by saying Most Latter-day Saints live in the USA, since only 41.2% of the church population worldwide live in the USA, and when you compare the various states with countries worldwide, you get some fascinating facts, to wit:

  • The Broadway play The Book of Mormon is heavily attended by suburbanites in Connecticut and pokes fun at pretended missionaries in Uganda. Facts:
    • There are more saints in Uganda than Connecticut.
    • There are over twice as many saints in Africa than there are in all of the New England / Northeast U.S. states combined.
  • If you add up the # of saints living in the 41 states (and DC) which are not the top 10 most saint-heavy states, you still dont get as many saints as there are in Mexico. Any wonder that Utah, the reddest of red states, nonetheless leans more liberal than most other red states when it comes to immigration reform efforts?
  • A dominant majority of the students at Brigham Young University speak a second language fluently because of their missionary experience in foreign countries. Only a minority of saints speak English as their native language.
  • There are more saints in Cote dIvoire than Alabama, and more in Zimbabwe than Mississippi.

What documents should we check before buying any land?

Once you decide to buy a plot, make sure you have all documents in place. Without these, your purchase will be delayed. Having all the proper legal documentation will help protect your land and home from any disputes in the future. Consult a lawyer to help you with every step of the documentation process.

Most of the required documents can be grouped into two types - legal and personal.

Legal documents: These documents are essential, and missing even one of these can result in a delay in purchase.

They include: -

Mother Deed: This is taken from the seller. The Mother Deed is the main document to d

Once you decide to buy a plot, make sure you have all documents in place. Without these, your purchase will be delayed. Having all the proper legal documentation will help protect your land and home from any disputes in the future. Consult a lawyer to help you with every step of the documentation process.

Most of the required documents can be grouped into two types - legal and personal.

Legal documents: These documents are essential, and missing even one of these can result in a delay in purchase.

They include: -

Mother Deed: This is taken from the seller. The Mother Deed is the main document to determine ownership of the property. It traces the lands chain of ownership and provides information about the history of the plot.

Sales Deed: The Sales Deed records the transfer of land ownership from the seller to the buyer. You can get it validated at the sub-registrar's office.

Power of Attorney(POA): If the seller of the land is not the owner, they should have a Power of Attorney that authorizes them to sell the plot. Always check the Power of Attorney when buying from any seller.

Encumbrance Certificate: An Encumbrance Certificate documents all the transactions related to the land. It serves as proof that the land you are buying is free of any monetary or legal bindings. It is obtained from the sub-registrars office where land is registered.

Katha certificate: A Khata Certificate is necessary to obtain a building license. It contains property details like location, size, built-up area etc. and is necessary for the payment of property tax and to obtain a building license. It is obtained from the Assistant Revenue Officer.

Land Clearance: If you wish to convert agricultural land to non-agricultural land this certificate becomes very essential.

Record Of Rights (ROR) certificate: It is obtained from the Tehsildars office

Personal documents: Personal documents are purely for verification purposes: Aadhar, Voter ID card and PAN card.

Things to keep in mind:

In case the seller is not the owner, check the power of attorney document.

To make sure measurements mentioned by seller are accurate, get a survey sketch of the land from Survey Department.

If there are more than one owner, make sure to get release certificate from all owners.

What is the process for sealing a non-member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS) in the temple?

In order to be sealed in the temple, you must be a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints. Also, you must be a current valid temple recommend holder. In order for anyone who is a non-member to be sealed in the temple, we do sealings for those who have passed away. Nobody who is alive and a non-member can participate in temple ordinances.

What documents should I get after closing a home loan in India?

The documents you should get after closing your home loan are:

The documents you should get after closing your home loan are:

1. Original Documents: You must get all the original documents you submitted to the lender at the time of availing the loan. Ensure that the documents are in good condition, with all the pages intact. The documents may include:

a. Sale Deed

b. Title Deed

c. Loan Agreement

d. Power of Attorney

2. No Dues Certificate: A No Dues Certificate (NDC) or No Objection Certificate (NOC) states that all dues have been settled and that the lender does not have any rights or claim on the property. Your NDC should mention critical details related to the housing loan (property address), customer name(s), the loan account number and amount, and the dates of starting and closing of the loan. It is advised that you make copies of the NOC so any future deals related to the property go smoothly.

3. Updated Non-Encumbrance Certificate: A Non-Encumbrance Certificate is a legal document containing detailed records of all financial transactions related to the property. Once you have settled your housing loan, the repayment should be reflected in the Non Encumbrance Certificate.

4. Post-dated Cheques: Your lender may have required you to submit post-dated cheques in the event of any missed EMI. If you have always been on time with your payments, make sure you retrieve all the submitted post-dated cheques.

In addition to these documents, there are two tasks that you need to complete:

1. Removal of Lien on the Property: At times, lenders may put a lien on the property. This effectively prevents the customer(s) from selling the property. In such cases, the lien must be removed after the repayment of the loan. To remove the lien, visit the Registrars Office along with an official from the lenders side.

2. Make Sure Your Credit Records are Updated: Check if your credit records are updated after you repay your home loan. Usually, it takes around 20-30 days for the repayment to be reflected in your credit history. Subsequently, request a credit report and verify the updated record.

Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints temples closed to the public?
Originally Answered: Why are Mormon (The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints) temples closed to the public?

The temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are in and of themselves offerings to God. They represent the very best Gods people can afford to construct.

Accordingly, access is strictly controlled.

Doesnt it make sense that a building should be limited to those who support and work towards the buildings intended purpose? My home is open to my children, their children and to a limited extent any friends of the familybut it is a home, it is a special place for my family.

Likewise, the temple is a special place for families who belong to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. It is where members of the Church of Jesus Christ make the very covenants that will allow the family to be sealed together forever. We see no obligation to expose sacred things to those, who like some of the folks who have answered this question, can only mock and deride those things that they cannot or will not understand.

I cant think of any building of comparable value to a temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that would simply throw the doors open and let you nose around.

The public is invited to tour every temple before they are dedicated. Come and see. We make a huge effort to accommodate everyone who is interested. But once the building is offered to God, it becomes sacred.

Ask yourself what happens to buildings open to the public. Are you able to keep them as beautiful and peaceful as you would like?

Would you keep your own home open to the public?

I think there is are perfectly sound reasons for the controlled access to the temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints just as there are reasons for controlled access to just about every building you can think of.

Obviously, one must first be endowed and have a basic understanding of what the temple is and how it works.

You must be recommended by your bishop to the temple president to be a worker.

The temple doesnt like to have workers who have young children at home, as they feel that ones first responsibility is to the family.

You cannot be a temple worker if you are in the bishopric or stake presidency (veil workers are OK).

They prefer that you be sealed to a spouse, but returned missionaries who are single are allowed.

Temple workers are expected to work a full shift in the temple. In the smaller temple in Nashville where I was a worker, that included both sessions on a weeknight. In larger temples, its usually about four hours, but they can adapt to your schedule.

You must have a regular time when you will be there, such as every other Tuesday or alternate Saturdays.

What is the Temple Endowment Ceremony of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
Originally Answered: What is the Mormon Temple Endowment Ceremony?

The temple endowment ceremony of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is a special spiritual blessing given to worthy and faithful members of the Church in the temple

What Is The Temple Endowment?

Your Personal Gift from God

Receiving your temple endowment is one of the most sacred experiences of your life. Personal preparation will make it more meaningful and powerful. Many members of the Church receive their endowment before a mission or marriage, while others simply have a strong desire to move forward along the covenant path. Regardless of the circumstances, it's important to realize that your endowment is more than just another step; its an essential and glorious part of your eternal journey.

Elder Russell M. Nelson reminded us that every activity, every lesson, all we do in the Church, point to the Lord and His holy house. Our efforts to proclaim the gospel, perfect the Saints, and redeem the dead all lead to the temple. Each holy temple stands as a symbol of our membership in the Church, as a sign of our faith in life after death, and as a sacred step toward eternal glory for us and our families (Personal Preparation for Temple Blessings, Ensign or Liahona, May 2001).

Only in the temple can we receive the ordinances necessary for us to be exalted in the celestial kingdom. Temple ordinances, including the endowment, lead to the greatest blessings available through the Atonement of Jesus Christ and help us focus on the Savior, His role in our Heavenly Fathers plan, and our commitment to follow Him.

The word endowment means a gift. In this context, the temple endowment is literally a gift from God whereby He bestows sacred blessings upon you. The endowment can only be received in His way and in His holy temple. Some of the gifts you receive through the temple endowment include:

  1. Greater knowledge of the Lords purposes and teachings.
  2. Power to do all that God wants us to do.
  3. Divine direction and protection as we serve the Lord, our families, and others.
  4. Increased hope, comfort, and peace.
  5. Promised blessings now and forever.

Members of the Church who are at least 18 years old may receive their temple endowment if they are faithful and prepared. Because temple ordinances and covenants are sacred and have eternal significance, members must be worthy and sufficiently able to understand the solemn responsibilities they will accept as they make covenants with God. Members who have received a mission call or are engaged to be married in the temple may receive the endowment. The bishop can also counsel with other adult members who wish to receive the endowment.

Your preparation to receive your endowment will include following the teachings of Jesus Christ and honoring the covenants you made at baptism. As you prepare, you will have the opportunity to meet with your bishop and then a member of your stake presidency for a temple recommend interview. They will ask you questions that allow you to share your testimony of the gospel of Jesus Christ, His living prophets, and His restored Church. Your answers will also affirm that you are diligently striving to keep Gods commandments.

An Overview

When you joined the Church, you received two ordinancesbaptism and confirmation. Likewise, the temple endowment is also received in two parts:

In the first part, you will privately and individually receive a preliminary ordinance called the initiatoryordinance. The initiatory ordinance includes special blessings regarding your divine heritage and potential.

In the second part, you will receive the remainder of your endowment in a group setting along with others who are attending the temple. During this part, the plan of salvation is presented, including the Creation of the world, the Fall of Adam and Eve, the Atonement, the Apostasy, and the Restoration, as well as instruction on how all people can return to the presence of the Lord. Some of the endowment is presented through video and some by temple officiators.

In conjunction with these ordinances, you will be invited to make specific covenants with God. These covenants include obeying God and keeping His commandments, living the gospel of Jesus Christ, keeping yourself morally pure and virtuous, and dedicating your time and talents to the Lords service. In return, God promises wonderful blessings in this life and the opportunity to return to live with Him forever.

At the conclusion of the endowment, participants symbolically enter the Lord's presence as they enter the celestial room. There you can spend time to ponder, pray, read the scriptures, or quietly discuss your experiences with family and friends. It is a place of peace, where you can also find comfort and divine direction.

Everyone participating in an endowment session is encouraged to carefully pay attention to what is being taught, but you are not expected to remember everything you hear. Temple workers will always be there to help and assist you. Your experience will be more personal and meaningful when you go with the intent to be taught by the Holy Ghost. Dont worry about getting everything the first time. It isnt a test, but an opportunity to feel closer to Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ. Focus on what you feel and the spiritual impressions you receive.

Draw Closer to the Lord

The temple endowment is a necessary step toward salvation and returning to Heavenly Father, but its also an opportunity to come closer to Jesus Christto know Him better and follow His example. Of course, all of the promised blessings of the endowment are dependent on our faithfulness.

After youve received your own endowment, you can return to the temple and participate in both initiatory and endowment ordinances for people who have passed away. As with all other ordinances performed in the temple, those who have died are aware of the service you have provided and can choose whether or not to accept what you have done on their behalf.

Your participation also allows you the chance to hear the blessings, instructions, and covenants again. Through your temple experiences, you will notice more ways the endowment relates to the plan of salvation and blesses your life. What you learn and feel will become clearer and more precious to you over time. As you visit, you will feel Gods love and be reminded of what matters most.

When did the temple endowment ceremony in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints begin, and what are the differences between the sacred temple garments when it began up to now?

Ill answer the second question first.

Temple garments were always regular underwear with the marks sown on. In the 19th century, everyone in society wore a union suit. This was a one-piece undergarment with a flap under the bottom and a flap in front for bathroom use. Everyone wore them. When the endowment was introduced, regular union suits were amended by sewing on the marks. When the Church moved to Utah and could produce its own clothing, this style stayed in fashion until the 1950s, when short sleeves and shorter legs were introduced. This has now come to a regular two-piece garment like

Ill answer the second question first.

Temple garments were always regular underwear with the marks sown on. In the 19th century, everyone in society wore a union suit. This was a one-piece undergarment with a flap under the bottom and a flap in front for bathroom use. Everyone wore them. When the endowment was introduced, regular union suits were amended by sewing on the marks. When the Church moved to Utah and could produce its own clothing, this style stayed in fashion until the 1950s, when short sleeves and shorter legs were introduced. This has now come to a regular two-piece garment like regular underwear. The church no longer makes a one-piece temple garment. Here is a video of the garments and the temple robes: Sacred Temple Clothing

The temple endowment ceremony had its beginnings in Kirtland in 1836 and was developed more fully in the temple in Nauvoo in the 1840s. It has continued to evolve over the years, becoming less repetitive and more socially aware of the needs of the members, while still retaining much of the form of the original ceremony.

Is a Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints considered a Church?
Originally Answered: Is a Mormon Temple considered a Church?

No and yes. Mostly No.

We don't call it a church and we don't do things in there that we do in church (we don't meet as a group with whoever shows up from the community to sing or have gospel centered lessons or play basketball or attend a Boy Scout meeting.) But the things we do in the temple are things that others do in their churches (weddings, reflection/prayer/meditation.)

So no we don't consider it a church technically. But yes it is a religious building used for religious purposes, so we wouldn't be offended if, when playing SimCity, "temple" was just a leveled-up "church."

In the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons), "Temple ordinances are not needed or performed" for babies who are stillborn or miscarried. Why?

Babies who are not born live are necessarily in one of two possible states:

  1. Never ensouled, and so not people. There's nothing there to do ordinances for.
  2. Ensouled, but dead prior to the age of moral accountability, and thus saved by default.

One can quibble over when exactly an embryo or fetus becomes a person, and miscarriage is a broad enough term that it could plausibly fall on either side of that line wherever you choose to draw itbut either way, no mortal ordinances are needed.

Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints temples so huge?
Originally Answered: Why are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon Church) temples so huge?

Theyre not all huge. Some, like the Salt Lake City temple, are large.

Salt Lake City temple (Image source)

But others, especially ones built in the last 20 years or so, are much smaller. The Raleigh, North Carolina temple in Apex, for example, is fairly compact.

Raleigh Temple in Apex, North Carolina (Image source)

Youll notice that it looks large, but thats due mainly to its construction and central spire. In reality, its not much bigger that a normal chapel, in terms of pure square footage.

But theyre large due to the number of rooms they house. Each temple contain a few ordinance rooms, whi

Theyre not all huge. Some, like the Salt Lake City temple, are large.

Salt Lake City temple (Image source)

But others, especially ones built in the last 20 years or so, are much smaller. The Raleigh, North Carolina temple in Apex, for example, is fairly compact.

Raleigh Temple in Apex, North Carolina (Image source)

Youll notice that it looks large, but thats due mainly to its construction and central spire. In reality, its not much bigger that a normal chapel, in terms of pure square footage.

But theyre large due to the number of rooms they house. Each temple contain a few ordinance rooms, which are used for sacred temple ceremonies. They also contain at least two changing rooms, where patrons can change into temple clothing. And, of course, they each have at least two restrooms. They also have offices for officials who work at the temple and a receiving area, like a lobby, where patrons can greet and wait for acquaintances.

Some have on-site cleaning facilities (for washing clothing) and some even have full cafeterias.

The ordinance rooms can vary in size, from the size of a large conference room to the size of a small movie theater. The ordinance rooms include:

  • Endowment room
  • Sealing room
  • Baptismal font
  • Celestial room

Of these, the baptismal font is probably the largest, as it contains a font, similar to this:

The oxen supporting the font represent the Twelve Tribes of Israel (Image source)

The Celestial Room can also occupy a good deal of space:

The Celestial Room is meant to suggest the Celestial Kingdom, or the highest degree of glory we all aspire to (Image source)

All these rooms together take up a lot of space. Larger temples often have multiples of these rooms, so they can accommodate more patrons.

Here is the official church site that goes into more details: Temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints - The House of the Lord

Do most members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints wear the temple garment even when they are not in church?
Originally Answered: Do most Mormons wear that special Mormon underwear even when they are not in church?

Now that members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have chosen to be called Latter-day Saints instead of Mormons, what do we call the Mormon temples?

Temples of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

Latter-day Saints Worship and Participate in Sacred Ceremonies in Temples

Temples are not meetinghouses and are closed on Sundays. They are considered Houses of Godliterallydedicated and kept sacred. Built to standards not used by any other buildings, the buildings themselves are offerings to the Creator. Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints must hold themselves to high standards of conduct and certify that they are worthy to enter. Temple Standard

We have been The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints for over 180 years. The term Mormons derives from Mormonites and is a derisive term first applied shortly after the publication of the Book of Mormon. Most do not realize that the term Mormons was designed to mock and marginalize the restored Church of Jesus Christ by those who felt threatened. We now ask the public to respect our desire to be called by the name given over 180 years ago. Section 115, For Thus Shall My Church Be Called in the Last Days

Weve tried to just be agreeable and accept the nickname, we even did a marketing campaign using the nickname. But, ultimately, it just doesnt workso now were done with that and would appreciate being called by the correct name. The name isnt new; it isnt something we have chosen recentlythe Churchs name was given by revelation in 1838. The only recent innovation is that we will now stand up and ask, politely, for people to adopt the correct usage. Its a simple courtesy really.

As to our temples, in practice, members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints follow a naming convention that begins with the city in which the temple is located followed by the state or country. For example, below is the Laie Hawaii Temple.

Image Credit: Laie Hawaii Temple

Above: Los Angeles California Temple

There is an exception to the naming convention for the headquarters temple, which is officially the Salt Lake Temple not the Salt Lake City Utah Temple. This is a structure that took forty years to build.

Another naming exception is the Mt. Timpanogos Utah Temple in Utah Valley, named after a prominent landmark rather than one of the many cities in the valley, presumably in a bid to prevent hurt feelings on the part of citizens of one of the many cities in the valley.

A similar exception exists for the Oquirrh Mountain Utah Temple.

Temples are symbolic representations of heavenly truths.

Here is a direct downward view of the San Diego California Temple showing the eight-pointed star design built into the skylight.

Here is a sealing room where eternal marriage ceremonies are performed. A stained-glass tree of life depiction is set into the window; additionally, in every sealing room, there are always a pair of mirrors facing each other, symbolizing this ceremony as a moment in an eternity of existence.

An image from inside the baptismal font of the Nauvoo Illinois Temple, which was rebuilt over a hundred years after the original was destroyed by mobs and weather.

The spiral staircase from the Nauvoo Illinois temple; symbolic of eternal progression

The baptismal font of the Jordan River Temple, symbolizing that the teaching and implementation of the Gospel of Jesus Christ is a particular responsibility of the children of Israel, who are represented by the twelve oxen upon whose backs the font restsall temple fonts follow this pattern, all the way back to Solomons Temple.

An artists depiction of the font from Solomons temple:

Murals from the Creation Room of the Los Angeles California Templeit is hard to see the scale in these pictures but they are huge and fill the entire wallspace of a room that seats some 300 people.

And, of course, every temple is built around a Celestial Room, which symbolizes the dwelling of God our Father. Below is the Celestial Room from the San Antonio Texas Temple.

This is the Celestial Room of the Cardston Alberta Templealmost 100 years old and designed in the Frank Lloyd Wright Prairie style. Ive been in this room and the detail in the woodwork is beyond description, intricate and tiny details everywhere.

Outside picture of Cardston Alberta Templeone of the few without an Angel Moroni statue on the top.

Boise Idaho Temple, Celestial Room

Exterior view Portland Oregon Temple

Oakland California Temple Celestial Room

A journey into the Holy of Holies in a Latter-day Saints temple J.

Temples are sacred to members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

We open them to public tours before they are dedicated, if one opens nearby, I would highly recommend taking the time to see one.

How many temple recommend holding Latter-day Saints (Mormons) do you think there are in the world?

How many temple recommend holding Latter-day Saints (Mormons) do you think there are in the world?

Theres a maximum percentage of the membership of the church, based on the age-structure thereof, and a minimum number, based on some positions that are virtually guaranteed to be occupied by temple-recommend holders. Between that, theres a wild guess based on personal experience.

Age-structure: If the church consisted entirely of adult converts who were baptized at the age of 21 years, went to the temple at 22, and died at 121, then one would expect up to 99% of those people to be current temple-recommend holders.

If the church consisted entirely of families who got married at 21 and had 18 children before the age of 40, with their parents and grandparents, then the majority of church members would be minor children, not old enough for a recommend.

If the church consisted mostly of single, widowed and married-to-nonmember women with up to 18 children each, then an even greater majority of members would be minor children.

So thats a range from well below 10% to above 90%.

Of course, the church is somewhere in between.

In my current ward, I think we have something like 30 primary-age children and 5 or 10 youth (teenagers) on the rolls, out of 300 or so total members; but thats not because 11-year-olds are dying, or being excommunicated, or having their names removed: its because the ward has a university within its boundaries, and a lot of graduate-student families come here with no or a few small children and move away when the parents earn their degrees. Im sure there are wards elsewhere with more youth than Primary children.

Since the number of convert baptisms per year is consistently larger than the number of new children of record, it may be that membership is somewhat skewed toward adults, at least more than what would be predicted by life-expectancy in a steady state alone.

But Id say the typical or average ward probably has above 200 adults who are age-eligible for a recommend.

Positions: There are just over 70,000 full-time missionaries.

[1]
Since most missions are for two years or less and the mission interview largely includes the temple-recommend questions, and a mission-president can conduct a recommend interview, it would be highly unusual for a missionary to be without a recommend for long enough to make a dent in that number.

There are just over 30,000 wards and branches, in just over 3,000 stakes. It would be highly unusual for a bishop or his counselors, or a branch president, to be without a recommend, since he is responsible for conducting the first temple-recommend interview; or for the stake president or his counselors to be without one, since they conduct the second.

There is a requirement of a minimum number of worthy (although not explicitly Temple-worthy) Melchizedek Priesthood holders to form a ward.

A functioning ward has a Ward Council made up of the bishopric, the Elders Quorum president or his delegate, the High Priest Group Leader or his delegate, and the various auxiliary presidents or their delegates: at least six additional people per ward. Theres not an absolute requirement that every member of every presidency be married or currently have a recommend, and often the spouses of some Ward Council members are also on or potential delegates to the council; but there are easily 160,000 members who are on a Ward Council, 300,000 who are counselors in presidencies such that they could be asked to attend Ward Council, and 200,000 who are spouses of one of those groups or a bishopric member but not on the Ward Council themselves, for a total of over 600,000 local-unit-position-related likely temple-recommend holders.

Other observations: With 3,000 members and recommends expiring on a two-year cycle, and the whole Stake Presidency able to conduct interviews, in a stake where 100% of the members held recommends, each presidency member would be conducting 500 interviews a year, on average about 10 a week.

My stake has standing open interviews at two locations, four times a month (two weekday, two Sunday). My sons Boy Scout troop meets down the hall from one of those times and locations. While Ive seldom explicitly counted, Id guess that the number of people obtaining recommends in one of those slots is usually between two and six, seldom if ever even close to ten. So thats definitely above 384 and perhaps about 1152 recommends renewed in those open interviews per cycle, almost certainly less than 1920.

The stake presidency also conducts interviews by appointment, but I have less visibility into those. Still, Im sure those add up over two years; perhaps another 100, perhaps another 500.

To keep recommends current for the whole ward, my bishopric would be conducting on average about three recommend interviews per week. Based on how they actually conduct their schedule, I dont think, on average, they conduct even one interview per week so probably between 50 and 100 temple recommend holders in my 300-person ward.

Overall guess: Between 1 million and 3 million, worldwide.

Should members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints be offended when people refer to them as Mormons or LDS on Quora?

Brigham Young once said something to the effect of, We should never take offense where no offense is intended. We should never take offense even when offense is intended.

Whether or not you consider Brigham Young as a prophet of God, which I do, he was an imperfect man. Still, this pearl of wisdom must come from something divine in him. It is one of the smartest things we could ever incorporate into our personal philosophy of life.

Many, many times in life I have corrected someone on using the incorrect term Mormon church.

The true name is The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

Howev

Brigham Young once said something to the effect of, We should never take offense where no offense is intended. We should never take offense even when offense is intended.

Whether or not you consider Brigham Young as a prophet of God, which I do, he was an imperfect man. Still, this pearl of wisdom must come from something divine in him. It is one of the smartest things we could ever incorporate into our personal philosophy of life.

Many, many times in life I have corrected someone on using the incorrect term Mormon church.

The true name is The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

However, rest assured that I do not ever take offense at being called Mormon. It comes from a book of scripture called The Book of Mormon, which is highly esteemed among us. It is named after the prophet and compiler of the booka great man named after a place where people had made sacred baptismal covenants with the Lord. It is a name of honor among us.

Still, that name is not the true name of the church; please do not take offense if one of us corrects the very common but inaccurate name Mormon. Even if you know that we know whom you refer to.

No Mormon or Latter-day Saint (same thing) should ever be offended by either the term Mormon or the acronym LDS. These should be very small things for us to forgive, given that we are commanded to love even our enemies.

How many times can you receive your endowment in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) before you are considered worthy to enter a Mormon temple on your own without having a companion present with you?

You receive your endowment in a single session in the temple. When you go for endowment sessions in the future you will be doing the ordinance for someone who is dead. Worthiness to enter the temple has nothing to do with how many times you have been there. You never have to have someone with you, although it is recommended to have an escort for your first time to help make sure you are in the right places.

I was 20 years old, and lived over 1000 miles from the nearest temple. There were no temple prep" classes at that time, and no other members of my immediate family had been to the temple, so I didn't know what to expect.

The Lord will bless you as you serve Him in righteousness."

Originally Answered: How was the experience in the Latter Day Saint temple like as opposed to a chapel?

The LDS Church holds weekly sacrament services in its chapels. All are invited to comeany age, whether or not they are, in fact, LDS members. The missionaries of the LDS Church, about 80,000, are trying constantly to persuade people to come and see for themselves. Chapels are kept neat and clean, but are built to traditional specifications for the areas in which they are located.

Now, the temple is considered a holy place. It represents an offering to God from His people. The LDS believe that the temple is the House of the Lord and each dedicated temple bears that inscription. A temple represents the absolute best building that the people can afford.

Any LDS temple is open to the public for a time after it is completed and before it is dedicated. In fact, if you wait, most temples are refurbished every 20 years or so in order to update mechanicals and replace tired or dated furnishings. The temple will be opened to the interested public and then rededicated afterwards.

LDS members (Mormons) believe that there are certain ordinances that are required to be obtained before one may re-enter the presence of God. We believe that the entire purpose of life is to give immortals (us) a chance to prove to themselves, God and everyone else, whether they will choose good over evil when they are outside the presence of God. The whole point of life is to see what we will do when left to our own decision-makingto give us a chance to exercise free will.

Because not everyone has the chance to really learn about God in this life, the LDS believe that there is a spirit world to which we all go after death in which this entire testing experience continues. People will have a chance to change and follow God even after death.

However, you need a physical body in order to be baptized and to receive the other essential ordinances. These ordinances are performed here on Earth inside temples on behalf of those who have already died. That is the whole point of the templeto help the family of God make and keep sacred promises.

The temple ceremony is considered most sacred by LDS members and we dont talk about specificsbut, suffice it to say that temple worship is much more symbolic and ceremonial than any LDS worship service outside the temple. Again, it gives people a chance to sort themselves outare you the kind of person who respects sacred things? Or the kind of person who mocks them?

Access to a dedicated and functioning temple is granted to those who have demonstrated that they believe in God and support the mission of the LDS Church. The ability to enter a temple is symbolic of ones ability to enter the presence of God. If you have transgressed commandments of God, you must repent and change before approaching God. You are interviewed twice by two separate leaders before being given a recommend that you would show in order to enter any LDS temple.

The entire purpose of the Mormon Genealogical and Family History work is to provide ordinances to those who have diedwe dont believe that people are required to or automatically accept such ordinances, but we do believe that it is our responsibility to provide them, to make them available. This is a huge effort. We allow anyone to helpsee Free Family History and Genealogy Records

Among the ordinances of the LDS Temple is the sealing ordinance. Men and women are sealed together for time and all eternity in temples; you can be simply married anywhereas a bishop, I performed time-only marriages for folks on the beach here in Laie, Hawaiibut for a marriage to last forever, you need to be in the temple.

Do members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) wear crosses?
Originally Answered: Do Mormons wear crosses?

Some do, most dont. We dont tend to think of jewelry as a symbol of our faith, and most of us would prefer to think of our symbol of faith being our good works rather than a torture device used to try to kill our God.

Were members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints required to take off all their clothes as part of temple initiatories in the past?

In order to put the gossip to rest, the short answer is yes.

The initiatory portion of the endowment has a washing, an anointing, and the clothing in the temple garment. In the early days of the Church, and in fact, right up to the 1950s, the washing and anointing had the patron naked. However, men were in the mens portion of the temple, and women in the womens section. Men and women did not see each other naked.

I have heard the following story from Benjamin Bowring, who was the first president of the Los Angeles temple. He performed our marriage and said this: When the Los Angeles Temple was dedicated, President David O. McKay wished to be the first person to receive the temple ordinances there, and he asked Brother Bowring to officiate. Brother Bowring told the President that he would be uncomfortable seeing the prophet of the Lord naked, so he took a bedsheet, cut a hold in the middle, and draped it over the prophet, then performed the ordinance, using only a small amount of water for the washing and oil for the anointing.

President McKay so liked the idea, he ordered it to become the standard of what would occur from them on. From that point up until the early 2000s, patrons wore a poncho-like garment called a shield, which was put on in a private locker. It was voluminous enough to cover everything down to the knees when held closed, and it was of a solid material that you could not see through. No one was seen naked, and the temple workers were quite delicate as they performed the washings and anointings.

Can a non-member marry a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in the temple?
Originally Answered: Can a non-Mormon marry a Mormon in the temple?

In order to answer this question, it's important to establish the distinction between an LDS meetinghouse and an LDS temple.

Meetinghouses are where members of the church congregate each Sunday to worship. It is also used during the week for fellowshipping activities, and as a place where missionaries can teach people who are not members, but interested in the church. All of these activities are open to all members and non members alike.

In order to answer this question, it's important to establish the distinction between an LDS meetinghouse and an LDS temple.

Meetinghouses are where members of the church congregate each Sunday to worship. It is also used during the week for fellowshipping activities, and as a place where missionaries can teach people who are not members, but interested in the church. All of these activities are open to all members and non members alike.

Temples, on the other hand, are considered a sacred place. It is known to us as the House of the Lord, and it's where we make sacred covenants with God, as well as performing those sacred covenants on behalf of our deceased ancestors who did not have the opportunity to make those covenants for themselves while living (on a side note, we believe these deceased ancestors still have the opportunity to reject covenants made in their name if they so choose). Because of the sacred nature of the temple, only members of the Church who have submitted themselves to an interview with their local clergymen in authority, in this case their Bishop and Stake President, and found worthy are allowed to enter. Not even all members of the Church may enter the temple.

So on this issue of marriage, the church recognizes that there are different levels of marital commitment. Having a civil marriage entitles us to being bound by our vows until death do us part. This type of vow can be performed in a meetinghouse. It can be between a LDS member, and someone who is not LDS. The other kind of marriage is what we refer to as a celestial marriage. It is performed in the temple, as it is considered not only a covenant to our intended spouse, but also a covenant to God. This type of vow entitles us to a marriage that exists for time and all of eternity, meaning that we are bound to our spouse even after death. We also believe that all children born to this couple under this covenant are bound to their parents after death as well, which is why we talk of eternal families. Because of the seriousness and gravity of this covenant, it is required that both intended spouses be baptized members of the Church, and both worthy to be admitted inside the temple.

When I met my now husband, he was not a member of the church. We were married civilly. Five years and two kids later, he decided to be baptized. We both worked to be temple worthy so that we could be married again, inside the temple. We refer to this as being sealed. Our children were then sealed to us. My experience with both types of marriage has reinforced my belief that a temple marriage is worth striving for. When you treat a marriage like its supposed to last forever, you put a lot more work into it, and you are more careful to not let it end, unless under the most dire of reasons. Of course there are those who do get married in the temple, only to divorce later. But my family has experienced a lot of benefits from our eternal commitment to each other.
